sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Chronic infantile neurological, cutaneous and articular syndrome: initial, 1 to 2 mg/kg SUBQ once daily; may increase in 0.5 to 1 mg/kg increments to MAX 8 mg/kg/day; may split into 2 daily doses
  • Rheumatoid arthritis: 100 mg/day SUBQ; administer dose at approximately the same time every day

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• effectiveness has not been established in children for rheumatoid arthritis
  • Chronic infantile neurological, cutaneous and articular syndrome: initial, 1 to 2 mg/kg SUBQ once daily; may increase in 0.5 to 1 mg/kg increments to MAX 8 mg/kg/day; may split into 2 daily doses
  • Chronic infantile neurological, cutaneous and articular syndrome, Treatment-refractory: 1 mg/kg/d SUBQ; may increase to 2 mg/kg/d SUBQ if no improvements in clinical or laboratory findings occur

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: renal impairment or end-stage renal disease (CrCl less than 30 mL/min:): administer prescribed dose SUBQ every other day

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Chronic infantile neurological, cutaneous and articular syndrome
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Chronic infantile neurological, cutaneous and articular syndrome, Treatment-refractory

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to anakinra or any components of the product
  • hypersensitivity to proteins derived from Escherichia coli

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• concomitant use of tumor necrosis factor blocking agents is not recommended
  • hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylactic reactions and angioedema, have been reported; discontinue therapy if occurs
  • infection, active; use not recommended
  • infection, serious, has been reported; discontinue if occurs
  • latex sensitivity; needle cover of prefilled syringe contains dry natural rubber (latex derivative)
  • live vaccines should not be administered concurrently
  • neutropenia has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • opportunistic infection may occur
  • renal impairment; potential increased risk of toxicity
  • tuberculosis (TB); increased risk of new onset or reactivation of latent TB
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Dermatologic:Injection site reaction (16.3%, neonatal-onset multisystem inflammatory disease; 71%, rheumatoid arthritis)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiorespiratory arrest
  • Dermatologic:Bacterial cellulitis, Malignant melanoma
  • Hematologic:Neutropenia (0.4%, rheumatoid arthritis)
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction, Infectious disease, Serious (2% to 3%), Malignant lymphoma
  • Musculoskeletal:Bacterial musculoskeletal infection
  • Respiratory:Bacterial pneumonia
  • Other:Breast cancer, Cancer

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Anakinra blocks the biologic activity of interleukin-1 (IL-1) by competitively inhibiting IL-1 binding to the IL-1 type I receptor. Produced in response to inflammatory stimuli, IL-1 mediates various inflammatory and immunological responses, and has activity involving cartilage degradation and stimulation of bone resorption. In rheumatoid arthritis patients, the levels of endogenous IL-1 receptor antagonist in synovium and synovial fluid are insufficient to compete with the elevated amount of locally produced IL-1. Patients with neonatal-onset multisystem inflammatory disease may have spontaneous gene mutations that lead to IL-1 beta secretion and increased systemic inflammation.

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Bile: minimal
  • Renal, rheumatoid arthritis: 80%, unchanged
  • Dialyzable: No (hemodialysis), 2.5%; No (peritoneal), 2.5%
  • Total body clearance: increases with increasing CrCl and body weight
  • Total body clearance, renal impairment: decreased by 16% to 75%

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
  • do not shake
  • administer the dose for rheumatoid arthritis at approximately the same time every day

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein, and rheumatoid factor levels
  • symptomatic improvement is indicative of efficacy
  • neutrophil count; prior to initiating therapy, monthly for the first 3 months of therapy, the quarterly for up to one year

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to report symptoms of an infection.
  • Advise patient to avoid live virus vaccines during therapy due to drug-induced immunosuppression.
  • Side effects may include injection site reactions, rash, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, flu-like symptoms, or arthralgia.
  • Advise patient about proper injection technique and placement.
  • Counsel patient to leave syringe at room temperature for 30 minutes prior to injection.
